title: IELTS Listening Test 04
content: Complete IELTS Listening Test 4 with all 4 sections (40 questions)

questions.instructions:
Questions 1-3

Choose the correct letter A-C
questions.question: How often does the man visit the Art Gallery?
questions.no_answer_feedback: You did not select an answer. The correct answer is B. Two to three times a year. In the IELTS test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is B.

mc_options.text: B. Two to three times a year
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The answer is B.

mc_options.text: C. Four to five times a year
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is B.

questions.options:
A. Once a year
B. Two to three times a year
C. Four to five times a year

questions.question: What section is the man’s favourite?
questions.no_answer_feedback: You did not select an answer. The correct answer is A. Traditional paintings. In the IELTS test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers.

mc_options.feedback: Correct! The answer is A.
Incorrect. The correct answer is A.
Incorrect. The correct answer is A.

questions.options:
A. Traditional paintings
B. Modern Art
C. Sculpture

questions.question: What publicity material is the man interested in?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is C.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is C.
Incorrect. The correct answer is C.
Correct!

questions.options:
A. Sales of paintings
B. New exhibitions of paintings
C. Talks about painters

Questions 4-5

questions.question: Item 1
questions.no_answer_feedback: No answer provided. In the IELTS test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers. 1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen to what the man says he looks at or buys in the museum shop.
1.no_answer: The correct answers include: new books, calendars, or souvenirs. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

questions.instructions:
Questions 9-10

Choose TWO LETTERS from the following list.

What areas does the man think need improving at the Art Gallery?
questions.question:
A. The range of exhibits
B. The frequency of new exhibits
C. Site of the Museum
D. Parking
E. Add a coffee shop
questions.no_answer_feedback: You did not select any answers. The correct answers are B. The frequency of new exhibits and E. Add a coffee shop. In the IELTS test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The man is happy with the range.
Correct! The man mentions new exhibits more often.
Incorrect. The man says the location is good.
Incorrect. The man says there is good parking.
Correct! The man suggests adding a café or coffee shop.

questions.options:
The range of exhibits
The frequency of new exhibits
Site of the Museum
Parking
Add a coffee shop

questions.instructions:
Questions 16-20

Complete the table below.

Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.

VIEWING ROOM SCHEDULE
questions.question:
Time Place Comments
Viewing Room A 11 a.m. 16[field16] Includes Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, etc.
11:45 a.m. Canada & USA Includes train trips, Hollywood, New York, etc.
1 p.m. Japan, Korea & China Includes temples, food, Great Wall, etc.
1:45 p.m. Britain & Europe Historical tours, castles, etc.
2:30 p.m. South America Includes 17[field17] Argentina, etc.
Viewing Room B 12:30 p.m. Travel in Europe Includes river and canal cruises, bus tours & trains
3 p.m. Overview of 18[field18] For new international travellers
questions.no_answer_feedback: No answer provided. In the IELTS test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers. questions.instructions:
Questions 36-40

Complete the summary below

Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.

DIFFERENT OPINIONS TO SAVING
questions.question:
People born between the years of 1945 and [field 1] have been observed to have more interest in saving than younger generations, younger people being more focused on their [field 2] situation than the long term.

Younger people would benefit from being given more information on [field 3] and long term planning so they can develop the ability to manage their own [field 4]. Many young people now find it impossible to save because of the increasing [field 5]. Advice from banks and other financial institutions could benefit customers.
questions.no_answer_feedback: No answer provided. In the IELTS test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers. Listen to the audio and review the transcript to understand where this information appears and how it's presented. Take notes while listening to help you remember key details.

1.correct: Correct! The Baby Boomer generation was born between 1945 and 1964.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for when the Baby Boomer generation ended.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is: 1964. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

2.correct: Correct! Younger generations focus on the present rather than the future.
2.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen to what younger people focus on versus long-term planning.
2.no_answer: The correct answer is: PRESENT. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

3.correct: Correct! Education about money management is vital for young people.
3.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what type of education young people need.
3.no_answer: The correct answer is: MONEY MANAGEMENT. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

4.correct: Correct! Young people need skills to manage their own budget.
4.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for what young people need to manage.
4.no_answer: The correct answer is: BUDGET. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

5.correct: Correct! Many struggle to save due to the increasing cost of living.
5.incorrect: Incorrect. Listen for why many young people find it difficult to save.
5.no_answer: The correct answer is: COST OF LIVING. Make sure to listen carefully for key information and take notes while listening.

sections.transcript: Section 1 W:   Hi, I was wondering if I could ask you a few questions about the renovations and changes made to the city Art Gallery.  It shouldn’t take more than 5 minutes. M:   Five minutes?  Ok, that shouldn’t be too long.  Sure, what do you want to know? W:  Well, one of the things we want to know is how often people visit the Art Gallery, and if they visit more than once a year?How many times would you say you come to the Art Gallery? M:  Oh, I’d say it depends, it depends on what exhibitions are on, usually more than once a year, probably 2 or 3 times.  I do like art, but I don’t come 4 times, haven’t usually got the time. W:  And what section do you like to visit? M:  Well, I do like the Old Master’s, it’s always the first section I see.  Not too keen on Modern Art.  I might have a quick look, and I usually see what sculptures they’ve added, but I always like to spend time with the Van Goghs and other classics. W:  I see.  Do you follow our publicity about new exhibitions?  New shows? M:  Well, not so much new exhibitions, but I do read any info on upcoming talks, when you have a speaker, especially aboutthe painters themselves. W:  Ok, thank you.  Now, one other area I’d like to look at is the Shop.  Do you ever visit the Shop in the museum? M:  Oh, yes, every time I go. W:  And what, if anything, do you buy?  What are you interested in? M:  Well, I always look at the [Q4: [Q5: books]], especially the new ones.  And I always buy a calendar, I like to give them as gifts.  And, then, I usually check out any souvenirs, or small items.  Anything new. W:  Ok, thank you very much for that.   W:  Now, if you don’t mind, can I just get a little bit of personal information, you don’t have to answer all of the questions,if you don’t want to. M:  Sure.  No problem. W:  Well, I don’t need your name, but can I ask your age group?  For example, are you 20-35, [Q6: 36]-50, or over 50? M:  Well, not quite a senior citizen, I’m in the 36 to 50 age group. W:  And can I ask your profession?  Your job? M:  Yes, I teach at City College.  I’m an [Q7: Economics] teacher. W:  And can you tell me what part of the city you live in?  The outskirts, the suburbs, the inner city? M:  Well, we can walk to the Gallery, so, I guess you could say we live in the [Q8: city centre]. W:  And, finally, you seem to be happy with the Art Gallery, but if you could, what changes or improvements would you like to see at the Gallery? M:  Hmm, that’s a good question.  Well, I’m pretty happy with the number of exhibits in general, and the range is good, butpossibly, the exhibitions could be changed, you know, new exhibits more often. W:  Ok, I’ll note that. M:  The location is good, easy to walk to and there is good convenient parking nearby.  One thing, though, maybe a café or coffee shop.  I know you can get a drink or snack in the shop, but I’d like some place to sit and relax and really be able to take in the experience. W:  Ok, that’s all good information.  Thank you, I’ll take note of that.  Now, if we can just…

Section 2 Woman:  Good afternoon, and welcome to the Travel Plus Travel Expo here in Victoria Bay.  My name is Jan Warfield, and I’m just going to give you a little bit of information about some of the exhibits here and the layout of the exhibition hall. Hopefully this will make it a little easier for you to find your way around and make your visit to the Travel Expo more enjoyable. Firstly, I hope you have all received your own [Q11: travel packs], which contain brochures and leaflets from some of the exhibitors. The travel packs also include some discount coupons, so make sure to take a look before shopping today.  Now, I’d like to hand out these information forms - remember to fill them out before the end of the day, because each form puts you in the raffle for a trip for two to any location in the [Q12: South Pacific], including flights with Island Airways. Now, let me tell you about what we have here in the exhibition hall.  When you first came in, you will probably have seen that there are booths already set up to let you know about all the offers available. On one side, you can find all the airlines that operate from here in Victoria Bay as well as other major cities on the west coast, and they continue all the way down the [Q13: right-hand] side of the exhibition hall.  You will be able to speak to the many representatives of the travel agencies as well as the airlines, both domestic and international, who have taken the opportunity to showcase their products. Now, lined up down the middle of the hall we have a number of hospitality organisations, such as the major hotel chains and some restaurants and vineyards. They would love to have the opportunity to speak with you as well, if you are thinking of a holiday overseas, or even a getaway here in our own country.  We also have a display from our own rail line, which as I am sure you know has just opened a wonderful scenic rail journey over the Central Mountains through to the capitol city.  Be sure to stop there and have a look at the video they have outlining the wonderful experience of taking the scenic train through the mountains, as well as the food and drink on offer in the dining carriage at the front and the brand-new rail carriages with glass rooves which allow you to take in the all the scenery. Next to the South Pacific tourism section, we have representatives from three cruise companies who operate cruise ships out of Victoria Bay through the [Q15: summer months], and one company is even looking at taking advantage of island cruises through the winter season as well, so I strongly recommend taking a look there. .    Now I’m very excited to let you know about something new we have for you at this year’s Travel Expo – the viewing rooms.  We have two viewing rooms and throughout the day, there will be a number of videos showcasing the different countries and locations you can visit.  The schedule for those videos is on a large display outside each of the viewing rooms, but I should tell you that Viewing Room A is slightly larger than Viewing Room B, although even in the smaller room you can still comfortably fit 50 people. I’ll just give you an idea of some of what they’ll be showing. Viewing Room A opens at 11 a.m., starting with a 20-minute presentation of travel through [Q16: South-East Asia], and this will include some wonderful panoramas of Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore and Malaysia, as well as other South-East Asian destinations. Additionally, representatives from travel organisations will be there to answer any questions about these destinations and they have many years’ experience in these locations, with some of them living there now.  The schedule continues with an [Q17: 11:45] a.m. viewing, and that will feature Canada and the United States, and the many wonderful experiences they have to offer, from train rides across Canada, to Hollywood, New York and all the big-city excitement that is North America.  Oh, and don’t forget the Grand Canyon in the U.S., as well as cruises from Vancouver in Canada up to Alaska. Following that, there is a short video showcasing Japan, Korea and China, which will be showing at 1 p.m., Europe and Britain, with all their history, are on at 1:45, South America, including [Q18: Brazil] and Argentina, at 2:30, and many more.  We hope there will be something for everyone! Finally, the other viewing room, Viewing Room B, will be showing videos of different traveling options, such as cruises, bus tours, river and canal cruises through Europe, at [Q19: 12:30], and for those relatively new to international travel, an overview of what [Q20: air travel] is like today, which will be on at 3 o’clock.  And this includes destinations, types of aircraft, et cetera.  I’m sure you’ll agree that there is something for everyone. Alright, enough from me, so enjoy your day.  Thank you very much, folks, and have a great time here at the Travel Expo.

Section 3  
Manager:  Come in, come in…, sit down… and you are… let’s see, Jason…?
Employee:  Yes, Jason [Q21: Endicott], with a double ‘t’,  E – N – D – I – C – O – T – T.
Manager:  Good, thank you.  Pleased to meet you, and welcome to the company.  My name is Debbie, Debbie Smith, and I’m the Commercial Manager here at Platinum Products.
Employee:  And I’m pleased to meet you, too, sir, and thank you for the opportunity to work here. I’m very excited to get started.
Manager:  Good to have you on board.  Now, I believe it was discussed during your interview with the HR department that you’ll be joining as a [Q22: junior] in the accounts department, but I hope you realise this is a real career opportunity. We see the role developing rather quickly, as we’re experiencing a significant level of growth at the moment.
Employee:  Yes, that was explained during the interview. I like the sound of the company, and what’s happening.  It must be an exciting time.
Manager:  Yes, it certainly is.  There are a lot changes underway at the moment the, and we’ve got new [Q23: export] markets opening up all the time. We’ve actually just signed a new contract in South East Asia, and as you know, the majority of your workday will be spent [Q24: monitoring] these new markets and formally presenting your feedback.
Employee:  Sure, no problem.
Manager:  I see that     you studied Economics and Business at University, so I’m hoping to draw on some of that knowledge while we work on developing these new markets.  What exactly did you study?
Employee:  Well, I did Marketing and Accounting, but I was particularly interested in Statistics, which was part of the Economics course.  I liked the numbers side of things, and I quite enjoyed looking at market trends and all the figures associated with that.
Manager:  That’s good.  That’s why we offered you the position, and we’re hoping to see some of that knowledge translated into analysing where we’re going, and how we’re going to get there.  Have you worked previously in any sort of industry position – I mean, have you done any similar work?
Employee:  Absolutely - I worked for Wilson Manufacturing last year for six months, a work experience sort of thing, and we were [Q25: investigating] a possible new project and working out the numbers to see if it was a good idea for the company.
Manager:  Interesting.  I hope some of that experience will carry over into this role.
Employee:  I’m sure it will.  I’m looking forward to getting started, and its especially exciting being a part of a new venture for the company and to be part of that growth.
 
Manager:  Well, let’s discuss some of the details of the job, and then we can get you started.  As was discussed in your interview, you will be working in the Sales and Marketing department alongside the accountant, where you will report to John Owens, the Manager there, but you will also be reporting to me as well, because I will be interested in those stats you come up with.
Employee:  Well, that will be interesting, with two managers, I mean.
Manager:  Well, we don’t see it as a problem. The departments generally communicate well with each other, and we think that your position will become increasingly important, as I mentioned before, so you’ll probably find you will need to work with a number of different departments.
Employee:  Is my position a stand-alone role, or do I work with others?
Manager:  That’s a good question.  Initially, you will be with two others, but we see the role becoming quite independent, so after a few months you will mostly be working by yourself.
Employee:  And if you don’t mind me asking, Ms Smith…
Manager:  You can just me call me Debbie – we’re quite informal around the office.
  OK, thank you Debbie. So, who will I receive my training from? Just to get me started, I mean.
Manager:  Ah, another good question….  John Owens, who I mentioned before, will be watching over you, as will I. However, John will be away for a few weeks from tomorrow, so I will be covering his role and my own. That means that, for the most part, the training will be done by Sharon Greenslade.  She’s the accountant that I mentioned before and has extensive knowledge of the sales side of things.
Employee:  Well, that sounds good.  It sounds as though I will have a lot of people I can draw knowledge from.  A silly question, perhaps, but do I have my own work station?
Manager:  Yes, in a moment I’ll take you through to where you’ll be working, but just to let you know you’re in a work station area with Sharon, who I just mentioned, and two others.  You will have your own desk and computer, of course.
Employee:  That sounds fine.
Manager:  Now, one thing I should tell you about is that there may be a requirement to work a few extra hours of overtime, which will be paid for in addition to your normal salary.  It’s just to prepare any reports that may be required and is most often only at the end of the month, but only in extreme cases. Saturdays and Sunday are your own though – we don’t ask staff to work then.
Employee:  Could I do that from home?
Manager:  Well, actually, that’s something we’re considering, and we might be moving to a situation where there is a lot of opportunity to do that. Our technical department are looking into making sure you can safely access information from outside of the office, but there are some security issues to be worked out. It would certainly help with parking – that’s often a problem here - and there are lots of other potential bonuses.
Employee:  That’s sounds great.
Manager:  I agree.  So…  Overall, what do you think?
Employee:  Well, as I said before, I’m excited to be working here.  It’s a very progressive company, and I want to be a part of it.  I hope I’ll be able to make a contribution.
Manager:  Yes, so do we, and we see you fitting in well.  As you may have been told by the Human Resources Department, there is a three-month review, at which time we can sit down and talk about how you’re doing, any concerns you might have, and how we see you moving forward. (fade)

Section 4 We have been looking at differences in attitudes of members of different generations and we are now going to consider the economic discrepancies between different age groups; this means the different attitudes they may display with regards to [Q38: money management]. Traditionally, in many cultures, older generations - let’s say the 45 and above age group - have attached a great deal of value to (Q31) [Q31: saving] money and also establishing security through buying their own home. According to Economist Simon Felder priorities are changing regarding both of these aspects for younger age groups in that they have been less important issues. We’ll look at saving and house buying individually. First of all, let’s consider home-ownership. Firstly, in countries such as the UK , while younger people may still have the desire to buy their own home, many under 30 year olds are actually unable to do so due to (Q32) [Q32: increasing house prices]. In many major cities in the UK , public sector workers such as (Q33) teachers or [Q33: nurses] are excluded from the property market due to economic pressures. There has also been a relatively recent trend for individuals with a higher than average disposable income to purchase two or more properties; one for their own use and the additional houses as investments which they rent out to tenants; this has also added pressure for (Q34) [Q34: first time buyers], as general property prices have increased as a result. Many younger people now need to remain in shared rental property or continue to live with their parents, as they find it impossible to buy their own home. People are also tending nowadays to settle into a romantic relationship later in life; many people not opting to (Q35) marry until their mid-thirties. Single people dependent on only one income often find it even more difficult to raise adequate finances to buy their own home. In response to the increased challenges in the housing market, some young professional people are now opting to invest in property with a friend, or even a like-minded acquaintance who also wishes to buy their first home, but is single and cannot afford the cost of a mortgage on their own.
Let’s move on now to the other point we raised earlier – that of saving money. Many sociologists believe that attitudes regarding long term planning versus the desire to obtain immediate gratification: that is ‘the wish have everything now’ vary quite dramatically in older and younger generations. According to Anne Hartwell, a prominent social scientist, the “Baby Boomer” generation (those born between (Q36) 1945 and [Q36: 1964]) tend to retain the traditional values of saving and moderation with regards to expenditure; whereas, younger generations of today have a tendency to spend money in the (Q37) [Q37: present] thinking less about the consequences of the future. Many educators believe that education about (Q38) money management and long term planning is vital for the youth of today. It is unrealistic to expect young people to act responsibly regarding their spending if little is done to ensure they have the basic skills to manage their own (Q39) [Q39: budget].While many subjects are taught in school, very few education institutions offer an insight into skills that will assist pupils with coping with real life once they enter the world of work. For many young people, saving money is extremely difficult, as the (Q40) [Q40: cost of living] rises a high percentage of the population struggle to meet the costs of day to day life. Anne Hartwell believes that banks, building societies and other such financial institutions offer additional support in helping their customers manage their finances so that fewer people fall into debt.
